attributes.Title: ST- Machado de Asis
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Portuguese
697R
UMass Amherst
This seminar will explore the work of Machado de Assis (1839-1908)  from his beginnings rooted in romanticism to his full development as the preeminent writer of fiction in Brazil, in many ways still unclassifiable and ahead of both his time and ours.   We will read most of his novels, many short stories, some poems, his important critical essays, and key works about him. Readings in Portuguese; course conducted in Portuguese.
Requirements: active participation in the seminar, with research and interpretive reports; several short papers during the semester; one long (final) research paper on a subject to be decided in consultation with the professor.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Title: Ideas That Change the World
attributes.Description:
Spring
2015
Honors College
201
UMass Amherst
In this seminar, students will examine texts and works of art that have profoundly shaped the world we live in. The course is divided into four units: Models of Inquiry; the Impact of Science and Technology; Social Philosophy and Civic Engagement; and Art in the World. The course is supplemented with several plenary lectures by distinguished honors faculty speakers.
This course is open to Commonwealth Honors College students only.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Title: Intro Port Lit I
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Portuguese
320
UMass Amherst
Introduction to the literature of Portugal from the Middle Ages to 1700. The main literary currents and techniques of the period and their relation to history and culture. Selections from representative poetry, drama, and narrative. Taught in Portuguese. Prerequisite: PORTUG 240 or consent of instructor.  (Gen.Ed. AL)
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
38496
Requisite: Introduction to the literature of Portugal from the Middle Ages to 1700. The main literary currents and techniques of the period and their relation to history and culture. Selections from representative poetry, drama, and narrative. Taught in Portuguese. Prerequisite: PORTUG 240 or consent of instructor.  (Gen.Ed. AL)

Spring
2015
Portuguese
408
UMass Amherst
Introduction to Brazil through contemporary film and literature.   (Gen.Ed. AL, G)
Class will meet once a week for lecture and discussions of the film and the assigned readings, and for student reports. Films will be seen individually at home (streamed via the library).
Study questions will be placed online week by week to guide you through readings and films.

attributes.Title: ST- Medieval & Renaissance Lit
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Portuguese
597MR
UMass Amherst
This course, open to both advanced undergraduate and to graduate students, surveys Medieval cantigas and historiagrafia; works by playwright Gil Vicente; literary representations of the story of Ines de Castro; the epic and lyric poetry of Camres; and the travel literature inspired by the Portuguese Expansion starting in 1415 and culminating in the loss of Portuguese Independence to Spain in 1580, the year of Camres' death.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Title: Brazil
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Portuguese
316
UMass Amherst
Introduction to Brazilian culture. Readings cover aspects of Brazilian history, economic and social development, folklore and the arts. Preliminary background for the in-depth study of Brazilian literature.  The course has a significant language component to help students improve their written and oral abilities in Portuguese.
Current topics in Brazilian culture and civilization presented by the lyrics of well-known Brazilian songwriters (Musica Popular Brasileira, Hip-Hop and Samba).
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
